awd_abstract_narration:
By using the electric power sector as an example of a critical infrastructure, this career project will examine the influence of computer and network security expertise on critical infrastructure organizations, the ways cybersecurity is becoming a new field of expertise and the role of global enactments of cybersecurity on reshaping conceptions of international security. This project will integrate research and teaching in order to identify options for policymakers, professional organizations and researchers to help engage cybersecurity research in professional organizations and analyses of organizational exercises. This project will inform practitioners, organizations, and policymakers about best practices for reducing risks to critical infrastructure. It will provide information to government and city planning for developing responses to global cybersecurity threats.  It will also develop interdisciplinary tools for teaching cybersecurity to the next generation of information security experts, control engineers, and public administrators.

This project will examines enactments of cybersecurity expertise at three distinctive organizational scales:  the micro - scale of small groups and individuals; the meso - scale of institutions such as corporations and standards - setting groups; and the macro - scale of political economy and international organization.  This multi-scalar analysis will explore technical and cultural approaches to risk to show how distinctive cultures of expertise negotiate risk are a multi - dimensional phenomenon; will identify the distinctive practices of information and physical  infrastructures and will address how cyberpower will impact within international relations. The project will develop best practices for critical infrastructure organizations to integrate computer and network security expertise into overall risk management strategies, drawing on participant-observation and semi-structured interviews with practitioners in the field.

por.por_cntn:
Rationale

As governments, corporations, and citizens have become critically dependent on cyberspace, so too have we come to depend on experts to secure this infrastructure. The United States and many other nations express concern about a shortage of skilled cybersecurity experts, even as attacks on critical infrastructure continue to grow. This project has developed an integrated program of research and teaching that both examines and advances cybersecurity expertise. It adopts a relational approach to expertise, conceptualizing it not simply as specialized knowledge and skills possessed by individuals, but as relationships between people who claim specialized knowledge and skills, and people who do not. This project examines how such relationships are enacted through practices such as socializing novices into expert communities, framing objects of expertise, and organizing knowledge-laden work.  

The enactment of cybersecurity expertise is particularly challenging because of disagreement about what cybersecurity means (both technically and politically) and how it can be achieved. This is one reason that, unlike engineers whose goals are more quantifiably demonstrated—a missile hits its target with a particular probability, computer chips fail at a known rate—cybersecurity experts cannot prove that a system is “secure.”  Furthermore, experts paradoxically demonstrate skills in cybersecurity by demonstrating insecurities—for example, hacking systems to reveal their vulnerabilities.

So how can experts offer any authoritative assurance of security? How have the skills, knowledge, and norms of this field been shaped by the diverse contexts (governmental, industry, civil society) in which cybersecurity experts must generate authority, credibility and trust? What does growing reliance on cybersecurity experts—and the multinational industry which in they often work—mean for national sovereignty and international relations?

This project used historical, ethnographic, and sociological methods to investigate these questions. Outcomes are summarized here under the heading of intellectual merits and broader impacts.

Intellectual merits

This project has developed several conceptual innovations, such as articulating distinct conceptions of offense-defense balance, and demonstrating principled reasons that we should not expect offense to always have the advantage in cyberspace; conceptualizing cybersecurity work and the associated labor relations in terms of care and maintenance; theorizing structural inequality as a form of cyber vulnerability in the United States; a framework for understanding how technology creates international vulnerability and resilience; and the articulation of distinct types of uncertainty and how they interact in cyber threat intelligence.

This project has also produced original empirical knowledge, including the first detailed historical study of how cybersecurity incident response was established and grew to become a global and transnational institution; the first original history of how cybersecurity expertise has gained authority and credibility in U.S. military commands; the first history of how cybersecurity professional certifications became a central means of credentialling cybersecurity experts, and the proliferation of certifications in the private sector; and a quantitative analysis of the relative costs and benefits of the Stuxnet cyberattacks on Iran’s nuclear enrichment facilities.

Broader impacts

This project adopted an engaged research strategy that advances both knowledge about and the creation of credible and trustworthy cybersecurity expertise, with the goals of creating partnerships between academia, government, and industry, enhancing national security, and furthering societal well-being.

For example, this project has fostered partnerships between academics and practitioners in cybersecurity, for example by bringing prominent practitioners to Cornell’s campus to engage in small group discussions with students and faculty, and by bringing academic research to practitioner conferences (for example, the PI gave a keynote at the Open Cybersecurity Conference in February 2024). The project has also articulated the difference between threat-oriented and vulnerability-oriented approaches to cybersecurity, and showed how the military valorization of threat-oriented approaches has structured military hierarchies and work in cyber commands in ways that may ironically make the United States more vulnerable. By tracing the origins of cyber vulnerability to specific choices about how to institutionalize the creation and maintenance of cyberspace, this project has also suggested specific pathways to enhance national security. Finally, it has also promoted societal well-being by reconceptualizing national security goals in terms of human security and the problem of structural inequalities.

These intellectual merits and broader impacts are embodied in the following outcomes:

  • 18 academic publications (articles or chapters)
  • 49 public presentations (31 invited talks, 18 peer-reviewed conference papers)
  • Two policy briefings
  • 1 practitioner-focused newsletter article
  • Book manuscript, Shadowing Cybersecurity (in progress)
  • Training for one postdoctoral researcher and three graduate students
  • The development of a new course, "Making Experts," that integrates research and teaching.
